bibl.title: Article: The Republic Remembers, by James E. Peabody, March 1928

div1.p: Peabody gives a brief history of the Yellow Fever Commission and discusses the pensions to be granted to the yellow fever volunteers after the passing of the Copeland-Wainwright Bill.

div1.head: Article: The Republic Remembers, by James E. Peabody, March, 1928
div1.p:
OUR Republic is not always forgetful; and the
stigma of apparent ingratitude will be forever
detached from it by one act of our Congress this
winter, if the pending Copeland-Wainwright Bill re-
ceives the merited public backing to insure its pas-
sage.

The bill not only advocates suitable pensions for
the survivors of the yellow fever experiments carried
on by Walter Reed and his associates in Cuba in
1901, but it makes provision that never again in our
history can such deeds of heroism go unnoticed. It
empowers the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian
Institution hereafter to recommend to Congress suit-
able pensions, awards, or other recognition, to citi-
zens employed in the service of the United States
“who through voluntary risk of life and health shall
have rendered conspicuous service to the people of
the country.” This act will put the heroes of peace
and progress on a par with those of war and disaster,
so far as national recognition is concerned.

This bill is the direct outcome of the present wide-
spread interest in helping the survivors of the yellow
fever experiments, and their dependents. The deeds
of these men are typical of the kind of services that
our country is eager to acknowledge. After the close
of the Spanish-American War, yellow fever broke
out among the American soldiers in Havana. A
commission to investigate its cause and transmission
was appointed, consisting of Major Walter Reed,
Dr. James Carroll, Dr. J. W. Lazear and Dr.
Aristides Agramonte.

Major Reed decided to investigate a theory that
the disease was transmitted by mosquitoes. Volun-
teers were called for and they permitted themselves
to be bitten by mosquitoes which had previously bit-
ten yellow fever patients. Lazear was exposed to a
contaminated mosquito, unintentionally, and died in
convulsions. Carroll almost died of the disease. The
experiments were continued on eleven men, and two
of them contracted yellow fever.

Then Reed and his associates established an ex-
periment station named Camp Lazear. Here the
first volunteer to be bitten under strictly experi-
mental conditions by contaminated mosquitoes was
John R. Kissinger, who developed a typical case of
yellow fever, from which he later recovered. This
showed that the disease can be transmitted by the
mosquito. To prove that the disease can not be ac-
quired by contact with contaminated objects, more
volunteers were exposed to the soiled clothing and
bedding used by men who had died of yellow fever.
Then followed a rigorous war upon mosquitoes. In
seven months, Havana was free from yellow fever.

The lack of any method of national acknowledg-
ment of the services of these experimentors of a
quarter century ago, has emphasized the need of
some official commission or other governmental ma-
chinery for providing suitable recognition for the
scientists, investigators, experimenters, and research
workers, who are continually risking life and health
as a part of their services to the public. In Europe,
royal recognition has been the traditional method
by which nations acknowledge such services, but the
United States, like all republics, has no such con-
venient method of granting unusual rewards.

Hence, in planning this measure, it was felt that
the primary emphasis should be upon our public and
official acknowledgment of the nation's sense of grati-
tude to those who have through risks and sacrifices
contributed notably to public welfare. Any refer-
ence to pension or annuity features should be made in
the form of expressing the nation's sense of obliga-
tion, not in the sense of offering a compensation for
services that can never be compensated. It should,
however, undertake to protect its beneficiaries against
suffering or privation.

The paramount concern at this time, however, is
to provide for the survivors of the yellow fever ex-
periments and for their dependents. These include
Mrs. Walter Reed; Mrs. James Carroll; Mrs. Jesse
W. Lazear; Dr. Aristides Agramonte; Pvt. John H.
Andrus, Hospital Corps; Mr. John R. Bullard; Pvt.
A. W. Covington, 23rd Battery, C. A. C.; Pvt. Levi
E. Folk, Hospital Corps; Pvt. William H. Dean,
Troop B, 7th Cavalry; Pvt. Wallace Forbes, Hos-
pital Corps; Pvt. P. Hamann, 23rd Battery,
C. A. C.; Pvt. James F. Hanberry, Hospital
Corps; Mrs. Warren G. Jernegan; Pvt. John R.
Kissinger; Mr. John J. Moran; Pvt. William Olson,
Hospital Corps; Pvt. Charles G. Sonntag, Hospital
Corps; Pvt. Clyde L. West, Hospital Corps; Dr.
R. P. Cooke; Pvt. Thomas M. England, Hospital
Corps; Pvt. James Hildebrand, Hospital Corps; Pvt.
Edward Weatherwalks, Hospital Corps.

The Bill provides therefore for a pension of $250.
a month hereafter for each of these cases, and then
empowers the Smithsonian Institute to make recom-
mendations to Congress covering each similar specific
case in the future. The provisions of the law are
broad enough so that any kind of award from a gold
medal or a monument to a land or money grant, or
a pension may be recommended.
